Raskolnikov was drawn to the chaos and music coming from the saloon below. ğŸ¶ He could hear someone dancing wildly, stomping to the beat of a guitar and a high-pitched voice singing a catchy tune. He leaned in closer, peeking from the sidewalk, feeling a mix of gloom and curiosity.

â€œOh, my handsome soldier, donâ€™t beat me for nothing,â€ sang the voice, and Raskolnikov was desperate to catch the lyrics, as if it held some kind of meaning for him.

â€œShould I go in?â€ he wondered. â€œEveryoneâ€™s laughing. Should I just get drunk?â€

â€œWonâ€™t you come in?â€ a young woman called out, her voice lighter and more pleasant than the others. She was cute, not at all unpleasant to look at.

â€œWow, sheâ€™s pretty,â€ he thought, straightening up to look at her.

â€œYouâ€™re not so bad yourself,â€ she replied with a smile, clearly flattered.

â€œIsnâ€™t he a bit too thin?â€ chimed in another woman, her voice deep and teasing. â€œDid you just get out of a hospital?â€

â€œThey all act like theyâ€™re fancy, but look at those snub noses,â€ a tipsy peasant joked, grinning as he wore his loose coat. â€œTheyâ€™re having a blast!â€

â€œShut it!â€ one of the women shot back.

â€œIâ€™m just playing, sweetheart!â€ he laughed, then rushed down into the saloon.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov is drawn to the lively atmosphere of a saloon, contemplating whether to join in the revelry.
